controls.title: Inventory and Control of Enterprise Assets
controls.summary: Actively manage laptops, servers, mobile, and networked devices to ensure only authorized assets access resources.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain detailed enterprise asset inventory
Use a passive asset discovery tool

scenarios.text: New laptops appear on the network with unknown hostnames.
scenarios.explanation: Active discovery and quarantine of unknown assets align to 1.2 and 1.3.

scenarios.text: Cloud VMs spin up outside change control.
scenarios.explanation: Sync cloud APIs into the inventory and tag owners (1.1).

why: Unknown or unmanaged devices expand the attack surface and complicate incident response.
Accurate inventories enable patching, configuration management, and risk decisions.
Zero Trust and least privilege depend on knowing what assets exist.
how: Deploy automated discovery (e.g., network scans, EDR) to enumerate assets.
Require unique asset IDs; record owner, purpose, sensitivity, and lifecycle.
Quarantine or block unknown devices via NAC or DHCP enforcement.
Continuously reconcile inventory with CMDB and cloud provider APIs.
metrics: Count of unmanaged assets by segment
checklist: Tooling in place to auto-discover assets
Owners and classifications captured for all assets

controls.title: Inventory and Control of Software Assets
controls.summary: Track, approve, and remove software to reduce attack surface and shadow IT.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a software inventory

scenarios.text: A user installs an unapproved remote access tool.
scenarios.explanation: Allowlisting and removal of unauthorized software (2.3).

scenarios.text: Out-of-support Java version found on critical server.

why: Unapproved or outdated software introduces exploitable vulnerabilities.
License and compliance obligations require visibility and control.
Attackers leverage unmanaged software for persistence.
how: Maintain an approved software list and enforce via allowlisting.
Inventory packages from endpoints, servers, and container images.
Block installation of unapproved software; remove unused packages.
Integrate SCA/SBOM to track components and versions.
metrics: Mean time to remove unapproved software
Count of vulnerable packages by severity

controls.title: Data Protection
controls.summary: Classify, handle, encrypt, and securely dispose of data to prevent loss and exposure.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a data management process

scenarios.text: Backups of sensitive data are stored unencrypted.
scenarios.explanation: Encrypt at rest and protect keys (3.4).

scenarios.text: Departing employee copies files to a USB drive.
scenarios.explanation: Apply DLP and media controls; secure disposal (3.6).

why: Data loss and exposure drive the highest business impact.
Regulations mandate specific handling and retention controls.
Consistent classification enables proportional protection.
how: Adopt data classification with handling and retention standards.
Encrypt data at rest and in transit; manage keys securely.
Implement DLP for email, endpoints, and cloud storage.
Sanitize media; verify destruction of retired assets.
metrics: DLP incident rate and time to close
checklist: Encryption defaults enabled (at rest, in transit)
DLP monitoring configured for outbound channels

controls.title: Secure Configuration of Enterprise Assets and Software
controls.summary: Harden configurations, remove defaults, and continuously enforce secure baselines.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a secure configuration process
Securely manage enterprise assets and software

scenarios.text: Internet-exposed server still has default credentials.
Drift detected on a Kubernetes node.

why: Default settings often enable unnecessary services and weak controls.
Consistent baselines reduce configuration drift and exposure.
Auditability and repeatability are essential for scale.
how: Adopt CIS Benchmarks or organizational baselines; document exceptions.
Automate configuration management (e.g., GPO, Ansible, MDM).
Continuously assess drift; alert on non-compliant changes.
Integrate config checks into CI/CD for images and IaC.
metrics: Number of exceptions and review cadence
checklist: Baseline defined per platform (server, endpoint, cloud)

controls.title: Account Management
controls.summary: Manage identities and privileges; enforce least privilege and timely deprovisioning.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain an inventory of accounts

scenarios.text: A contractor account remains active after project end.
scenarios.explanation: Disable dormant accounts and automate JML (5.6).

scenarios.text: Admin access without MFA on a remote VPN.

why: Excess privileges and stale accounts enable lateral movement.
Lifecycle management reduces insider and orphaned-account risk.
Principle of least privilege limits blast radius.
how: Centralize identity with SSO; automate provisioning/deprovisioning.
Apply RBAC/ABAC and periodic access reviews.
Enforce MFA for remote, admin, and sensitive access.
Protect service accounts with vaulting and rotation.

controls.title: Access Control Management
controls.summary: Approve and enforce access to data and systems with MFA and segmentation.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain an access control policy
Require MFA for remote network access

scenarios.text: Sensitive finance folder accessible by all employees.
scenarios.explanation: Define and enforce RBAC; review access (6.5).

scenarios.text: Remote users access internal apps without MFA.

why: Unauthorized access leads directly to data breaches.
Segmentation limits movement and data exposure.
Strong auth and approvals reduce exploitation.
how: Define access request and approval workflows.
Enforce MFA and conditional access for sensitive resources.
Segment networks/data; apply least privilege.
Log and review access changes.
metrics: MFA coverage for privileged and remote access
Mean time to revoke access on departure
Failed access attempts and anomaly rates

controls.title: Continuous Vulnerability Management
controls.summary: Routinely discover, prioritize, and remediate vulnerabilities across assets.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a vulnerability management process
Remediate vulnerabilities in accordance with SLAs

scenarios.text: Critical CVE with active exploit found on DMZ server.
Scan coverage misses Linux instances due to creds issue.

why: Unpatched vulnerabilities remain a leading initial access vector.
Prioritization focuses effort on exploitable risk.
Continuous visibility is needed as environments change.
how: Scan routinely; include authenticated scans and cloud APIs.
Prioritize using EPSS, exploit availability, and asset criticality.
Patch or mitigate within defined SLAs by severity.
Track remediation and verify closure.

controls.title: Audit Log Management
controls.summary: Collect, retain, and analyze logs to detect, investigate, and recover.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain an audit log management process

scenarios.text: A breach investigation fails due to missing logs.
Parsing errors cause dropped events in SIEM.
scenarios.explanation: Harden ingestion and parsing; validate coverage (8.1).

why: Insufficient logging impairs detection and forensics.
Retention supports investigations and compliance.
Centralization enables correlation and alerting.
how: Define log sources, formats, and retention times.
Forward logs to a SIEM with parsing and basic detections.
Protect logs from tampering and loss.
Test that critical events generate alerts.
metrics: Parsing success rate and dropped events

controls.title: Email and Web Browser Protections
controls.summary: Reduce phishing and browser-based attacks with filtering, isolation, and controls.

safeguards.title: Ensure use of only fully supported browsers and email clients
Block unnecessary file types and protect against macros
Deploy and maintain email anti-malware protections

scenarios.text: Users receive phishing emails with malicious macros.
scenarios.explanation: Block risky file types and macro execution (9.4, 9.6).

scenarios.text: Employees browse to newly registered malicious domains.
scenarios.explanation: Use DNS filtering to block malicious domains (9.2).

why: Phishing remains a top initial attack vector.
Malicious web content delivers payloads and credentials theft.
Layered controls mitigate user error.
how: Enable anti-phishing, attachment sandboxing, and URL rewriting.
Harden browsers; restrict extensions and legacy plugins.
Use DNS and web filtering to block malicious sites.
Train users and run phishing simulations.

controls.title: Malware Defenses
controls.summary: Deploy and maintain anti-malware across endpoints and servers with alerting.

safeguards.title: Configure automatic anti-malware scanning and updates

scenarios.text: Ransomware spreads via SMB before alerts are seen.
scenarios.explanation: Enable real-time protection and central telemetry (10.3, 10.6).

scenarios.text: Anti-malware signatures are stale on remote laptops.

why: Commodity malware and ransomware are pervasive threats.
Detection and response reduce dwell time.
Behavioral analytics catch novel variants.
how: Deploy EDR/AV with automatic updates and policy enforcement.
Enable real-time protection and periodic full scans.
Integrate alerts into SIEM/SOAR workflows.
Test response playbooks for common malware.

controls.title: Data Recovery
controls.summary: Perform reliable, tested backups and rapid recovery for critical data and systems.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a data recovery process

scenarios.text: Backups were encrypted by ransomware along with production.
A critical database restore fails due to missing logs.
scenarios.explanation: Automate backups and validate restore steps (11.2, 11.6).

why: Backups are the last line of defense against data loss.
Ransomware recovery depends on clean, offline copies.
Testing validates RTO/RPO assumptions.
how: Identify critical data and set RTO/RPO objectives.
Maintain immutable/offline backup copies.
Automate backup schedules and monitor success.
Test restore processes regularly.

controls.title: Network Infrastructure Management
controls.summary: Secure, standardize, and manage routers, switches, and network services.

safeguards.title: Ensure network infrastructure is up-to-date and supported

scenarios.text: Switch configurations are lost after a hardware failure.
Admins use unsecured protocols to manage routers.

why: Misconfigurations expose services and enable interception.
Standardization reduces errors and speeds recovery.
Visibility is needed across hybrid/on-prem/cloud.
how: Harden device configs; disable unused ports/services.
Centralize logging, backups, and configuration management.
Use secure management protocols and MFA for admin.
Document network topology and ownership.

controls.title: Network Monitoring and Defense
controls.summary: Detect and respond to anomalies using IDS/IPS, telemetry, and alerting.

safeguards.title: Alert on attack patterns and anomalies

scenarios.text: Exfiltration via unusual DNS tunneling goes unnoticed.
scenarios.explanation: Collect flows and alert on anomalies (13.2, 13.4).

scenarios.text: No detection for lateral movement between subnets.

why: Network telemetry provides early indicators of compromise.
East-west visibility helps detect lateral movement.
Detection coverage complements endpoint controls.
how: Deploy IDS/IPS and flow analysis at key chokepoints.
Collect DNS, proxy, and firewall logs centrally.
Create detections for data exfiltration and C2 patterns.
Hunt using behavior baselines and threat intel.

controls.title: Security Awareness and Skills Training
controls.summary: Build a culture of security with role-based training and phishing tests.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a security awareness program
Train workforce members to recognize social engineering

scenarios.text: Phishing simulation failure rate is high for finance team.
Developers repeatedly introduce injection flaws.

why: Human behavior influences most attack paths.
Targeted training improves outcomes vs. generic modules.
Simulations reinforce learning and measure risk.
how: Map curricula to roles and risks.
Run phishing exercises with feedback.
Include secure coding and cloud training for engineers.
Track completion and effectiveness metrics.

controls.title: Service Provider Management
controls.summary: Govern third parties: contracts, security requirements, monitoring, and offboarding.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain an inventory of service providers
Establish and maintain service provider security requirements

scenarios.text: A SaaS vendor suffers a breach affecting your data.
Terminated provider retains VPN access.

why: Third-party compromises propagate into your environment.
Clear requirements and monitoring reduce inherited risk.
Offboarding ensures access is revoked.
how: Define security requirements in contracts and SOWs.
Assess providers proportionally to data and access.
Monitor performance and incidents; enforce SLAs.
Revoke access promptly at contract end.

controls.title: Application Software Security
controls.summary: Integrate security into SDLC: design, code, test, and fix vulnerabilities early.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a secure software development process
Establish and maintain a software vulnerability remediation process

scenarios.text: A critical vuln ships to production due to missing checks.
scenarios.explanation: Add testing gates and remediation process (16.6, 16.11).

scenarios.text: New feature introduces auth bypass.

why: Fixing defects earlier is cheaper and safer.
Supply chain risk requires component visibility.
Security by design reduces recurring flaws.
how: Define secure coding standards and threat modeling.
Automate SAST/DAST/SCA in CI/CD with gates.
Protect secrets and use signed builds/artifacts.
Provide developer training and secure patterns.

controls.title: Incident Response Management
controls.summary: Prepare, detect, triage, contain, and recover with tested IR plans.

safeguards.title: Designate personnel and define IR roles

scenarios.text: Confusion during ransomware response delays containment.
Team has never practiced a cloud incident.

why: Prepared teams reduce impact and downtime.
Clear roles limit confusion during crises.
Exercises reveal gaps before incidents.
how: Define IR policies, roles, and communication plans.
Create playbooks for priority threats (ransomware, BEC, data loss).
Train and run tabletop/technical exercises.
Post-incident reviews drive improvements.

controls.title: Penetration Testing
controls.summary: Validate defenses and improve detection through planned, scoped testing.

safeguards.title: Establish and maintain a penetration testing program
Perform periodic external and internal testing

scenarios.text: Recurring critical findings appear across tests.
Scope omits critical crown-jewel applications.

why: Realistic testing validates assumptions and controls.
Findings inform prioritization and risk decisions.
Improves blue team detection and response.
how: Define scope, rules of engagement, and success criteria.
Use a mix of automated and manual methods.
Retest to validate remediation and track trends.
Coordinate with IR to exercise detection.
